Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Pacific-Arctic Carbon Synthesis - Transformations, Fluxes, and Budgets.
Award.AbstractNarration: Predicting future conditions of the Arctic Ocean system requires scientific knowledge of its present status as well as a process-based understanding of the mechanisms of change. This research effort will synthesize a number of recent, upcoming, and historical datasets to create three regional carbon budgets for the Chukchi/western Beaufort Sea, the Bering Sea, and the northern Gulf of Alaska. As waters from the North Pacific make their way through these regions a number of transformations occur that modify them before they enter the central Arctic Ocean. In general, the waters exiting these shelf seas are fresher, colder, and have lower pH due to the uptake of CO2 and the remineralization of organic matter. Because of the importance that biogeochemical transformations have in preconditioning the waters of the central Arctic and ultimately parts of the North Atlantic it is important to gain a better understanding of how these processes impact the carbon biogeochemistry of the region. The investigators propose to address this issue by better constraining the carbon budgets for three zones in the Pacific sector of the Arctic Ocean including coastal fluxes, rates of primary production and air-sea exchange of CO2 as well as developing algorithms with predictive capabilities for carbonate mineral saturation states. The aim of this effort is to determine how physical forcing and biological responses control the marine carbon cycle including the rates of air-sea CO2 exchange and net community production as well as ocean acidification effects in the contrasting shelf environments, and to better constrain the present stocks and fluxes of carbon and determine how climate change will affect the regional carbon cycle. The project will support four early career investigators, a postdoctoral scientist, and a Ph.D. student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The Arctic is undergoing rapid transformations that have brought it to the top of international scientific and political agendas. Predicting future conditions of the Arctic Ocean system requires scientific knowledge of its present status as well as an understanding of the mechanisms of change. In recent years a number of US and International field efforts have begun to fill in the data gaps across sectors of the Arctic, but this work is being done in a time of unprecedented environmental change.  Sea ice is diminishing in the region and the retreat of seasonal sea ice in the marginal ice zones has begun to occur earlier and persist longer.  This, along with changes in land environments and warming temperatures, have likely cascaded into Arctic ecosystems.

Of particular importance are flows of carbon through Arctic ecosystems, and potential changes in these with warming and sea ice loss, since these have the potential to result in important positive or negative feedbacks. It is critical to gain a better understanding of how processes such as air-sea exchange of CO2 gas, delivery of dissolved and particulate carbon to coastal areas by rivers, and marine photsynthesis and biomass decay impact the carbon balances of each region. This project focused on synthesis of a number of recent and historical datasets to evaluate carbon budgets for 3 main sectors of the Pacific Arctic: the Chukchi/western Beaufort Sea, Bering Sea, and northern Gulf of Alaska.  Several key outcomes include research publications detailing seasonality of air-sea CO2 exchange in Arctic regions that have identified a potential reduction in Arctic CO2 uptake due to fall and winter season outgassing of carbon related to storm activity and sea ice loss. A new accounting of the annual carbon budget for the SE Bering Sea which takes into account recent observations of water column processes (photosynthesis, respiration, benthic activity) measured during a large-scale field campaign (Bering Ecosystem Study) was also produced. Finally, because high quality carbon observations are often scarce, this project supported the development of algorithms that allow us to predict carbon from more commonly measured variables like temperature, oxygen, and nutrients. These algorithms are available for the northern Gulf of Alaska region, and are currently being developed for the Pacific Arctic region.

Broader Impacts:

This work has supported several junior scientists (a Ph.D a student, a postdoctoral researcher, and an early career scientist) and has contributed to career development opportunities at all levels. The work has produced several research publications, and many talks at scientific conferences, and the results have already stimulated new lines of research in this very important climate-sensitive region. In addition, the lead PI on the project (Mathis) conducted several town hall meetings in coastal regions of Alaska to publicize results of this work.
